questions.text: Which of the following is not useful in measuring cardiac output?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Central venous catheter Central venous catheter alone is not useful for measuring cardiac output. Various methods to measure cardiac output are as follows: Pulmonary artery flotation catheter (PAFC): Use dye dilution and thermodilution techniques (bolus and continuous thermodilution cardiac output monitoring) Arterial waveform analysis Thoracic electrical bioimpedance Fick partial rebreathing method (uses CO 2 ) Aortic Doppler (transesophageal and transcutaneous) Point-of-care Echo (transthoracic as well as transesophageal)—LVOT is analyzed for cross-sectional area (CSA) and velocity time integral (VTI). Cardiac output (CO) is measured by the formula CO = CSA × VTI × HR Lithium dilution (uses peripheral vein) Combined lithium dilution and pulse contour analysis

Highyeild:

Physiological variations of cardiac output Age : Cardiac output is more in adults than in children because blood volume is more. Gender : cardiac output is more in male than females. Altitude : cardiac output increases at high altitude places. Pregnancy :cardiac output increases during pregnancy Exercise :cardiac output increases during exercise Emotion :cardiac output increases during emotional expressions PATHOLOGICAL VARIATION OF CARDIAC OUTPUT Pathological increase: Hyperthyroidism Fever Pathological decrease: Hypothyroidism Hypovolumia Haemorrhage Myocardial infarction

Extraedge:

REGULATION OF STROKE VOLUME Regulated by three variables: End diastolic volume (EDV): volume of blood in the ventricles at the end of diastole. Sometimes called preload Stroke volume increases with increased EDV. Total peripheral resistance: Frictional resistance in the arteries. Inversely related to stroke volume Called after load Contractility : strength of ventricular contraction Stroke volume increases with contractility . Ejection fraction (EF) - percentage of the EDV that is ejected per cardiac cycle. Stroke volume = EDV - ESV EF% = (SV / EDV) × 100 Normal ejection fraction is about 50-65%.

questions.text: How to differentiate tamponade from tension pneumothorax?

options.label: D
options.text: Not improving after initial fluid resuscitation

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breath sounds Pericardial tamponade and tension pneumothorax can both result from thoracic trauma. Cardiac catheterization shows elevated right atrial pressure with the loss of the descent Both result in distended neck veins or a high central venous pressure (CVP). Both may not improve after fluid resuscitation as both of them are classified under obstructive shock. Pericardial tamponade involves the following : Pulsus paradoxus : Exaggerated decrease in arterial pressure during inspiration (>10 mm Hg drop) Electrical alternans : This is alterations of the axis of the QRS complex on ECG, manifested as the height of the QRS complex. Distant (muffled) heart sounds. CXR : Clear chest with normal air entry. Enlargement of cardiac silhouette when >250 mL has accumulated. Tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension with the onset of cardiogenic shock.m Breath sound present in pericardial tamponade. Tension pneumothorax i nvolves the following: Look for respiratory distress CXR: Shift of trachea away from side of pneumothorax Breath sounds absent Hyperresonance to percussion on the side of pneumothorax

Highyeild:

Tension pneumothorax occurs when communication between injured lung and parietal pleura becomes a one-way valve without any outflow from the pleural space. The pressure in the pleural space increases causing hypoxia, mediastinal shift, and can compromise venous return as well. Clinical presentation of a pneumothorax can range anywhere from a symptomatic to chest pain and shortness of breath. A tension pneumothorax can cause severe hypotension (obstructive shock) and even death. Beck's triad describes symptoms commonly associated with tension pneumothorax. The three components of Beck's triad are: Distended neck veins Muffled heart sounds Hypotension Other symptoms include tachypnea, dyspnea, tachycardia, and hypoxia. Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis and treatment should never be delayed by waiting for radiological confirmation. Management - Immediate decompression by insertion of a large bore needle into the second intercostal space in the midclavicular line of the affected side then followed by insertion of a chest tube through the fifth intercostal space in the anterior axillary line.

Extraedge:

Pneumothorax refers to the presence of air in the pleural space. It may occur spontaneously or due to trauma (latrogenic) to the lungs or the chest wall. Spontaneous pneumothorax occurs due to the rupture of pleural blebs. latrogenic injury occurs while performing any thoracic, cardiac or any chest wall surgeries. questions.text: A patient presents with recent onset of breathlessness. An ECG is taken (shown below). What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) ECG shows narrow complex tachycardia with irregular rhythm. Since P waves are seen it rules out AF. Different morphologies of P waves (≥3) in lead II rules out sinus arrhythmia. All the above said features confirm MAT . Also, absence of chest pain and significant ST elevations rules out AMI. At least 3 different P wave morphologies: Rate 100 to 180 Irregular

questions.text: A 60-year-old female patient has left-sided weakness since 1 hour and left-sided facial weakness with BP 160/100 mmHg. The CT scan is normal. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Give loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Start thrombolysis It is a case of ischemic stroke. Treatment of Stroke Thrombolytics : Before anticoagulating in order to rule out a hemorrhagic stroke see the head NCCT (non contrast CT). In this case, CT brain is normal suggesting there is no hemorrhage. Patient is in a window period (4.5 hours), so the next step is thrombolysis with Alteplase/Tenecteplase. Thrombolytic agent [ recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA)] use between 3 and 4.5 hours after the onset of stroke symptoms is useful in selected patients. Ideally, thrombolysis done within 3 hours produces better neurologic outcomes. <20 % of patients with a stroke come in time to get thrombolytics (<3 hours). Catheter retrieval of clot : If the patient is coming after 5 hours, his/her clot has to be removed with a catheter. This is useful up to 6–12 hours after stroke.

Highyeild:

BP Control Antihypertensive agents given if the following three conditions are present: The patient’s BP is very high—SBP > 220, DBP > 120, or mean arterial pressure > 130 mmHg). The patient has a significant medical indication for antihypertensive therapy. Examples include the following: Aortic dissection Hypertensive encephalopathy Acute MI Severe heart failure IV Nicardipine/Clevidipine or Labetalol is the first-line agent to control blood pressure. Surgery Surgical management: Decompression to prevent herniation if cerebellar hematoma or superficial hemorrhage of cerebral white matter is there. Carotid artery stenosis is managed by endarterectomy .

Extraedge:

Contraindications to thrombolytic therapy : Presence of bleeding disorder Stroke within 1-year of cerebral trauma or brain surgery within 6 months Presence of intracranial neoplasm/mass Active bleeding or surgery within 6 weeks Previous history of hemorrhagic stroke CPR within 3 weeks that was traumatic (e.g., chest compressions) Suspicion of aortic dissection There is no standard role for double antiplatelet therapy (Aspirin + Clopidogrel) in ischemic stroke (except in certain extremely special scenarios). Even if aspirin is given it has to be given ≥24 hours post-thrombolysis . Only if thrombolysis or any intervention cannot be done/need not be done, Aspirin can be given as soon as possible after CT. Antiplatelet medication : Aspirin or clopidogrel or aspirin combined with dipyridamole is acceptable as an initial antiplatelet medication to prevent a subsequent stroke. Aspirin : Best initial therapy for those coming too late for thrombolytics. Aspirin is given only after 3 hours of stroke. It is best if given within 24 hours of symptom onset. Clopidogrel : If the patient has developed a stroke on aspirin, then switch to clopidogrel. Dipyridamole : If the patient is already on aspirin when a new stroke or transient ischemic attack occurs, add dipyridamole or switch to clopidogrel.

questions.text: Which of the following cannot be diagnosed without positive ANA?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Systemic lupus erythematosus A patient has SLE if four or more of the following criteria are present at any time. Diagnostic Criteria for SLE Mucocutaneous signs (each counts as one) • Malar rash • Photosensitivity rash • Oral ulcers rash • Discoid rash Arthritis Present in 90% of patients; nonerosive Cardiac and pulmonary Pericarditis, myocarditis, Pleuritis (most common pulmonary finding), pleural effusion, pneumonitis, pulmonary hypertension Hematologic (any blood involvement counts as 1 criteria) Hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia Renal It begins from proteinuria >0.5 g/day to endstage renal disease, such as cellular casts, glomerulonephritis, azotemia, pyuria, uremia, HTN Cerebral Seizures, psychosis (may be subtle), meningitis TIA, cerebrovascular accident Serology Note: Each of the serologic abnormalities counts as 1 criterion. Hence, if the person has joint pain, a rash, and both an ANA and DS DNA, that patient would have 4 criteria. • ANA. It is 95% sensitive but not specific; almost all patients with SLE have elevated serum ANA levels • Anti-ds DNA (60–70%) or anti-Sm (Smith) (10–20%). The presence of either of these is diagnostic of SLE—very specific (but obviously not sensitive) Diagnostic Test for SLE Best initial test : ANA Most specific test : Anti-DS DNA (60–70%) or anti-Sm (Smith) (10–20%). ANA positivity is a must in SLE diagnosis. ANA negativity twice rules out SLE. Also drug-induced lupus —secondary to Quinidine/Minocycline—tends to be ANA negative.

Highyeild:

Musculoskeletal manifestations of SLE: Arthralgia Non-erosive Symmetric Polyarthritis Jaccoud's deformity due to ulnar deviation. Hip joint osteonecrosis Swollen effusion, Morning deformity Tenderness of >2 joints

Extraedge:

Clinical manifestations of SLE: M - Malar rash Butterfly rash, sparing of nasolabial folds D- Discoid rash disc-shaped scarring S-Serositis Pleuritis, Pleural effusion, Ascites, Pericarditis O- Oral ulcers O typically painless over hard palates A-Arthritis small joints, non-erosive, similar to RA, deformities are correctable P-Photosensitivity B - Blood Abnormalities AIHA, Thrombocytopenias, o Neutropenia R - Renal abnormalities A- Abs ANA, Anti-SM 1 - Immunological problems N-Neurological (Organic brain syndrome) Cognitive decline Seizures Psychosis Headache

questions.text: Which of the following is not done before ABG:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flexion of wrist While taking ABG the wrist is generally kept in hyperextension. This is to make the vessel straight and to fix the position (because of tension in hyperextension). Flexion will make the vessel loose and the vessel will slip easily while poking. ABG is painful, and radial artery spasm can result in ischemia of the hand in patients with radial dominant circulation.

questions.text: While measuring blood pressure of a cardiac tamponade patient, what advice will you give him?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breathe normally The ability to document pulsus paradoxus. BP documentation of pulsus. Paradoxus requires the patient to breathe normally and does not require any special maneuver.

Highyeild:

Diagnosis: ECG- Electrical alterations JVP waveform- Prominent 'x' descent and absent 'y' descent Chest X-ray: Large, globular or pear-shaped heart with sharp outlines.

Extraedge:

The accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space in a quantity sufficient to cause serious obstruction of the inflow of blood into the ventricles results in cardiac tamponade. The three principal features of tamponade (Beck's triad) are hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention with a prominent x (early systolic) descent but an absent y (early diastolic) descent. Paradoxical Pulse: This important clue to the presence of cardiac tamponade consists of a greater than normal (10 mmHg) inspiratory decline in systolic arterial pressure. When severe, it may be detected by palpating weakness or even the disappearance of the arterial pulse during inspiration. Because both ventricles share a tight incompressible covering, i.e..., the pericardial sac and the inspiratory enlargement of the right ventricle cause leftward bulging of the interventricular septum, reducing left ventricular volume, stroke volume, and arterial systolic pressure.

questions.text: A patient has ECG with “mean” axis of 90°. In which lead there would be the maximum voltage of R wave?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

aVF 90° cardiac axis corresponds straight to lead aVF and hence as such maximum “R” wave amplitude would be seen in that lead only. The frontal plane leads are represented on hexaxial diagram.

Extraedge:

The electrical activity of the heart starts at the sinoatrial node then spreads to the atrioventricular (AV) node. It then spreads down the bundle of His and then Purkinje fibres to cause ventricular contraction Whenever the direction of electrical activity is towards a lead you get a positive deflection in that lead Whenever the direction of electrical activity is away from a lead you get a negative deflection in that lead. The cardiac axis gives us an idea of the overall direction of electrical activity. Axis interpretation using the schematic illustration demonstrates the relationship between QRS axis and the frontal leads of the ECG.

questions.text: Reason for thyroid storm after thyroid surgery are:

options.label: D
options.text: Rough handling of thyroid at surgery

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inadequate preoperative preparation Thyroid storm is a condition of hyperthyroidism accompanied by fever, central nervous system agitation or depression, and cardiovascular dysfunction. Spontaneous thyroid storm in a patient with Grave’s most commonly occurs due to infection . Thyroid storm after thyroidectomy mainly occurs due to inadequate preoperative preparation. Occasionally, thyroid storm may result from amiodarone administration or exposure to iodinated contrast agent or following RIA therapy. Treatment for Thyroid Storm Propylthiouracil to prevent peripheral T4 to T3 synthesis Lugol’s iodine up to 30 drops Sodium iodate/potassium iodide infusion intravenously Propranolol for decreasing heart rate Steroids to prevent adrenal exhaustion. Digoxin for atrial fibrillation Diuretics for CCF

questions.text: Death due to smoke inhalation is due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Anemic hypoxia In smoke/fire, patient generally dies of excess CO poisoning (most frequent cause of death). If there is low PaO 2 , it is called hypoxic hypoxia. In smoke (CO poisoning), PaO 2 will be normal and the problem is COHb. An abnormal Hb or reduced Hb concentration comes under anemic hypoxia. Hypoxemia (low PaO 2 ) can happen if the rapid fire consumes a lot of oxygen and the FiO 2 in the atmospheric air reduces to ≤ 15% (normal 21%). Hypoxemia can also result from non cardiogenic pulmonary edema/ARDS after toxic smoke. Hence, ideal answer would be A + B (or) B > A. But since a single option is needed, B is chosen.

questions.text: What is the difference between RIFLE and KDIGO criteria in differentiating a tubular injury?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Urinary NGAL RIFLE originally used urinary sodium, urine osmolarity, Fe Na , to define tubular dysfunction/injury. Currently, urinary NGAL/Kim-1/Cystatin C/L-FABP all are being evaluated as more sensitive and specific markers of tubular injury (KDIGO 2017/18). RIFLE Criteria for acute kidney injury (AKI) Risk: 1.5-fold increase in the serum creatinine or GFR decrease by 25% or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours. Injury: Twofold increase in the serum creatinine or GFR decrease by 50% or urine output <0.5 mL/kg/h for 12 hours. Failure: Threefold increase in the serum creatinine or GFR decrease by 75% or urine output of <0.5 mL/kg/h for 24 hours, or anuria for 12 hours. Loss: Complete loss of kidney function (i.e., requiring dialysis) for more than 4 weeks. ESRD: Complete loss of kidney function (i.e., requiring dialysis) for more than 3 months.
